issue.title: Unable to build azure-storage-blobs from version 12.8.0

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue requires a change to an existing behavior in the product in order to be resolved.

labels.name: question
labels.description: The issue doesn't require a change to the product in order to be resolved. Most issues start as that

labels.name: Client
labels.description: This issue points to a problem in the data-plane of the library.

labels.name: customer-reported
labels.description: Issues that are reported by GitHub users external to the Azure organization.

issue.body:
***Exception or Stack Trace***

Observing the below error while compiling the azure-storage-blobs-12.8.0
```CMake Error at sdk/core/azure-core-amqp/CMakeLists.txt:33 (find_package):
  Found package configuration file:

    /usr/local/cmake/uamqpConfig.cmake

  but it set uamqp_FOUND to FALSE so package "uamqp" is considered to be NOT
  FOUND.  Reason given by package:

  The following imported targets are referenced, but are missing:
  aziotsharedutil

-- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
See also "/code/repo/thirdparty/azure-sdk-for-cpp/.build/CMakeFiles/CMakeOutput.log".
```

**To Reproduce**
Build the latest or 12.8.0 azure-storage-blobs

***Code Snippet***
Unable to find dependent packages `azure-uamqp-c` installed at system path `/usr/local/` or custom path

**Expected behavior**
CMake build should work w/o any configuration errors and build successful

**Setup:**
 - OS:
 ```
[root@02f90f531dbc .build]# g++ --version
g++ (GCC) 13.2.0
[root@02f90f531dbc .build]# cat /etc/os-release 
NAME="Red Hat Enterprise Linux"
VERSION="9.2 (Plow)"
```
 - Version of the Library used
```
[root@02f90f531dbc azure-uamqp-c]# git branch 
* (HEAD detached at LTS_07_2022_Ref02)
[root@02f90f531dbc azure-sdk-for-cpp]# git branch 
* (HEAD detached at azure-storage-blobs_12.9.0) 
```
other libraries version
```-- Found CURL: /opt/anzograph/tools/lib/libcurl.so (found version "8.1.2")  
Libcurl version 8.1.2
-- Found OpenSSL: /usr/lib64/libcrypto.so (found version "3.0.7")
```

**Additional context**
1. `azure-uamqp-c` is built succesfully with below 
```[root@02f90f531dbc .build]# cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DCMAKE_CXX_STANDARD=20 -DBUILD_TESTING=OFF -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -DCURL_INCLUDE_DIR="${AZG_HOME}/tools/include" -DCURL_LIBRARY="${AZG_HOME}/tools/lib/libcurl.so" -DDISABLE_AZURE_CORE_OPENTELEMETRY=ON ..
[root@02f90f531dbc .build]# make install

[root@02f90f531dbc .build]# ls -l /usr/local/include/
total 16
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Sep 28 09:40 azure_c_shared_utility
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Sep 28 09:40 azure_macro_utils
drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Sep 28 09:40 azureiot
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Sep 28 09:40 umock_c

[root@02f90f531dbc .build]# ls -l /usr/local/lib64/
total 1348
drwxr-xr-x 1 root root   4096 Aug  9  2021 bpf
drwxr-xr-x 3 root root   4096 Sep 28 09:40 cmake
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 533914 Sep 28 09:40 libaziotsharedutil.a
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 706972 Sep 28 09:40 libuamqp.a
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 126358 Sep 28 09:40 libumock_c.a
```
2. `azure-sdk-for-cpp` is bulid with 
```
[root@02f90f531dbc .build]#cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DCMAKE_CXX_STANDARD=20 -DBUILD_TESTING=OFF -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -DCURL_INCLUDE_DIR="${AZG_HOME}/tools/include" -DCURL_LIBRARY="${AZG_HOME}/tools/lib/libcurl.so" -DDISABLE_AZURE_CORE_OPENTELEMETRY=ON ..
```

I tried to pass CMake flag `CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH:STRING=${AZURE_UAMQP_INSTALL_PREFIX}` with custom path for installed `azure-uamqp-c` targets in step (2)

comment.body:
@ahsonkhan,

Thanks for your comment. Please find more details below

We could see the `sdk/core/azure-core-amqp` depends on the `azure-uamqp-c` (which additionally requires `azure-c-shared-utility`	`azure-c-testrunnerswitcher`  `azure-ctest`  `azure-macro-utils-c`  `umock-c`) and required while building the `azure-storage-blobs`.

About the environment used,
1. The RHEL 9 platform with customised GCC13.1 tool-chain and on the same platform we were able to build `azure-storage-blobs` successfully before the 12.8.0 version.

2. When trying to build the latest version >= 12.8.0, 
a. First builb and install `azure-uamqp-c` with CMake's default install prefix path `/usr/local/include/`. The generated output is placed in `/usr/local/include` and `/usr/local/lib` due to the non-system package.
b. Building azure-storage-blob using below
```
cmake .. -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DCMAKE_CXX_STANDARD=20 -DBUILD_TESTING=OFF -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -DCURL_INCLUDE_DIR="${AZG_HOME}/tools/include" -DCURL_LIBRARY="${AZG_HOME}/tools/lib/libcurl.so" -DDISABLE_AZURE_CORE_OPENTELEMETRY=ON
make install
```
4. We pull `azure-sdk-for-cpp` as part of the build system and generate respective libraries and consume.

5. Initially, we tried to use vcpkg, but couldn't. This could be due to we want to use a custom toolchain (GCC13.1) and the latest `libcurl`, `libnghttp2,` etc on the RHEL 9 platform at a custom path.
I also think we should align.

comment.body: I'll merge this PR first. This doesn't affect #5071 because they fix different problems.

Do we want to align with libcurl implementation? 

https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-cpp/blob/50c18516df110058e1faac27b38360bc56db7c6e/sdk/core/azure-core/src/http/curl/curl.cpp#L428

Libcurl adds `Content-Length: 0` if the request method is not `Get`, `Head`, `Delete`?

review.body:
Thank you, @janbernloehr!
This behavior existed since the beginning, and it is hard to tell right away, how, if, and where it would affect us.
This looks like a breaking change - previously a user would parse `2023-10-26T18:18:18` and get UTC value, now they'll get a different value.

FWIW, format behavior is consistent with .NET:
```cs
Console.WriteLine(DateTime.Parse("2023-10-26T18:18:18").ToLocalTime()); // When ran in PST time zone, prints "Oct 26, 2023 11:18:18".
```

I think #5075 should be fixed tactically in the Azure CLI credential - it could be that `DateTime::Parse()` gets something like a `treatNoTimeZoneAsLocal = false` third parameter, or something like that. And then the AzureCLI credential passes that flag to the `TokenCredentialImpl`, and then its token parser uses that flag when parsing the token expiration time.

cc @ahsonkhan

pull_request.title: Azure-Core: If no timezone information is present in string, assume local time and convert to UTC

review.body:
Thank you @janbernloehr!
This behavior existed since the beginning, and it is hard to tell right away, how, if, and where it would affect us.
This looks like a breaking change - previously a user would parse `2023-10-26T18:18:18` and get UTC value, now they'll get a different value.

FWIW, format behavior is consistent with .NET:
```cs
Console.WriteLine(DateTime.Parse("2023-10-26T18:18:18").ToLocalTime()); // When ran in PST time zone, prints "Oct 26, 2023 11:18:18".
```

I think #5075 should be fixed tactically in the Azure CLI credential - it could be that `DateTime::Parse()` gets something like a `treatNoTimeZoneAsLocal = false` third parameter, or something like that. And then the AzureCLI credential passes that flag to the `TokenCredentialImpl`, and then its token parser uses that flag when parsing the token expiration time.

cc @ahsonkhan

issue.title: Ensure CMakeLists don't miss any files

labels.name: EngSys
labels.description: This issue is impacting the engineering system.

labels.name: Storage
labels.description: Storage Service (Queues, Blobs, Files)

comment.body:
I don't completely understand, we are picking one approach here, which is by-directory.
Codegen does not produce cmakelists.txt files.
If anything, I would rather drop the separation at all, and just use single list - it does not we use that distinction in any meaningful way anywhere, we just combine them at the earliest convenience.
I would not even declare a variable like we do today - just feed all the files to CMake `add_library()` call - that variable with a list of files is not used anywhere else anyways.
We can briefly discuss this topic during our C++ sync meeting.

But I think we should just go with what `cmake-format` can offer us, plus look into what VisualStudio and VSCode support by default (they can add files once you add them inside an IDE, it is just currently we never accept what they generate because they generate paths with quotes and wrong indentation; but all that may change once we integrate with cmake-format).

So for that reason, I think the issue tracking this that you're looking into is the #5066. Whichever the auto-format (with avaliable config tweaks) can produce for us - that's the format that we should use. The rest does not matter that much.

comment.body:
Command 'check-enforcer' is not supported by Azure Pipelines.

Supported commands
  • help:
    • Get descriptions, examples and documentation about supported commands
    • Example: help "command_name"
  • list:
    • List all pipelines for this repository using a comment.
    • Example: "list"
  • run:
    • Run all pipelines or specific pipelines for this repository using a comment. Use this command by itself to trigger all related pipelines, or specify specific pipelines to run.
    • Example: "run" or "run pipeline_name, pipeline_name, pipeline_name"
  • where:
    • Report back the Azure DevOps orgs that are related to this repository and org
    • Example: "where"

See additional documentation.

issue.title: az cli returns expiresOn in local time but sdk assumes c++ time
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When using an AzureCliCredential, the `ExpiresOn` field is parsed from the the output of the call
```
az account get-access-token --output json --scope "https://storage.azure.com/.default"
```
which returns the field `expiresOn` in local time but does not add time zone information. However, `Azure::DateTime` assumes - when no time zone information is present - that the date is in UTC.

The `IsFresh` method of Azure::TokenCache then compares the parsed `ExpiresOn` with `Azure::DateTime(std::chrono::system_clock::now())` which is UTC time thus yielding a wrong comparison.

***Exception or Stack Trace***
-

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Inject the following debug code in `TokenCache::IsFresh` in `token_cache.cpp`:
```
  const DateTime end_point = DateTime(now) + minimumExpiration;
  std::cout << "lhs: " << item->AccessToken.ExpiresOn.ToString() << " rhs: " << end_point.ToString() << std::endl;
```
Then call any api using the `AzureCliCredential` that requires a token.

***Code Snippet***
-

**Expected behavior**
The AzureCliCredential should correctly take the time zone information into account.

**Screenshots**
-

**Setup (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Ubuntu 22.04
 - IDE : VsCode
 - Version of the Library used: Azure Identity `1.6.0-beta.1` and Azure Core `1.10.2`

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

**Information Checklist**
Kindly make sure that you have added all the following information above and checkoff the required fields otherwise we will treat the issuer as an incomplete report
- [x] Bug Description Added
- [x] Repro Steps Added
- [x] Setup information Added
